wikipedia_page.main: Henry Field (29 September 1755 – 19 December 1837) was an English apothecary.

response: * Mrs. Henry Field  (1897–1994), see Nancy Lancaster
* Henry Field and Robert Hunter Semple, Memoirs of the Botanic Garden at Chelsea (1878), p. 88.

Field was the second son of Henry Field, a London surgeon and apothecary, and Esther, née Barron. Barron Field was educated as a barrister, being called to the Inner Temple on 25 June 1814. In 1811 he published an analysis for students of Blackstone's Commentaries (with a second edition in 1817).  He was a great student of poetry and frequently contributed to the press, being for a time theatrical critic for The Times. He became acquainted with Charles Lamb and his circle; Crabb Robinson called on Field in January 1812 and found Lamb and Leigh Hunt there, and he records in another place that at Lamb's house on 23 May 1815 he met William Wordsworth, Field, and Thomas Noon Talfourd.

He was born in London, the son of Henry Field, and educated at Christ's Hospital and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he obtained a fellowship in 1824. He was ordained in 1828, and began a close study of patristic theology.

Isaac was probably son of James Rand, who in 1674 agreed, with thirteen other members of the Society of Apothecaries, to build a wall round the Chelsea Botanical Garden.Henry Field and Robert Hunter Semple, Memoirs of the Botanic Garden at Chelsea (1878), p. 12. Isaac Rand was already an apothecary practising in the Haymarket, London, in 1700.
